In all, 402 individuals are known to have participated in the groups regis¬
tered with the Project office. It is estimated that an additional five to six

The average size of the groups was twelve persons.
An estimated ten thousand persons listened regularly to the radio program,
(Details on a radio survey appear later in the report.)
Of the thirty-four groups registered, twenty-three stayed together for the
entire series, which lasted until the second week in June.
Organizing Principle.
Most of the groups met in private homes, and these ranged from very luxurious
houses to very modest ones.
Three kinds of organizational principles were discovered: (^) natural
'’friendship” groups; |2) block groups; and (3) groups consisting of people drawn
from the same formal organization (service club, P-TA, churches, etc.)
Of these, the ’'friendship" groups were the most successful from these stand¬
points: persistence of the group; growth in size; quality of discussion; spontaneity
of participation; and personal satisfaction expressed by the people involved. A$
used in this report, "friendship group” has a broader meaning than referring only to
an existing group of friends. The term also includes people whom the organizer
thought would enjoy each other. Usually these groups ripened rapidly into hsting
"friendship” groups.
The block groups were the least successful. In all cases of those registered,
the "block groups" disintegrated early. In some cases block groups were converted
by the organizer into friendship groups. This had the effect of a blood transfusion
in restoring vitality to the affected group.
